ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was grounded in a critical approach to migrant and refugee narratives in literature and how they shape our understanding of displacement, borders, innocence, nostalgia and the spectacle that is the migrant.

I learned not only to write about my own experiences/my family's experiences but also how to do so carefully and thoughtfully. I developed the ability to hone in and look closely at the narrative I wanted to build and the story I wanted to tell. I also learned a lot about how stories of refugees and migrants are presented, and how different forms can elucidate different pieces of their stories - and how some parts will always remain opaque.
This class taught me a lot about close looking, close reading, and thinking through ideas of migration, displacement, and home. It was really an amazing class.
This class was incredible! I  have never taken a narrative-based class before and it was wonderful. I loved the readings and was able to better my writing and breadth of writing styles.

Developing a critical lens for literature, understanding the tropes of refugee representation, learning about the work of translation and compromise in a narrative, analyzing how the structure/form of a piece connects to the politics of its content, unpacking the role of agency across multiple voices in my own work (why would an author choose to represent their subjects this way?)

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: interesting readings, engaging discussions, and the biggest strength in my opinion was the way the assignments kind of all led up to the final project so we were working on it throughout the semester

Weaknesses: need more variety in modes of learning, sometimes it was just 2 hours straight discussion with one random 5-10 minute break which made it hard to concentrate

Strengths: I loved the content of the course and the at it was taught! There was a strong emphasis on learning and being careful and generous. Weaknesses: since we were moving a bit slow and specific, we didn't always cover as much as ground as would've been nice.

This class had a fantastic selection of readings, all of which Leah Mirakhor helped us understand much better with her insights. The final project was flexible and enough that we were able to really write and create what we cared about   for many of us, it was exploring our own personal family migration stories and their context.
I loved it!

Responding to each other's discussion posts before class made online engagement much more meaningful compared to just posting each week on a Canvas wall bereft of actual conversation. Also, workshopping our final projects within small groups and then presenting to the larger seminar made it easier to track progress as well as build confidence in my choices as a writer.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Zoom was OK and screen sharing was nice for presentations and comments. Hand-raising was also okay  Ultimately, it was a seminar so it obviously would've been nice to chat in person.
It was all great, I wish it could have been in person but our class was small and I think we all got to know each other very well regardless.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: yes!
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student, especially one who is interested in first-person writing about migration.
Yes! Absolutely :)
I would definitely recommend it. Prof. Mirakhor was legendary throughout it!

Absolutely--Professor Mirakhor does a wonderful job of facilitating such illuminating conversations, and the other students stick with the course because they're deeply invested in it. This makes for an unparalleled seminar experience, one that stood out during a pandemic semester and remains one of the best classes I took during undergrad.

Yes absolutely, TAKE THIS COURSE! This class was amazing, I have never taken an English-style narrative class before unless I had to for WR credits, but I loved this class. The readings were all very engaging and just simply good books.  Professor Miraakhor is amazing, one of the best professors I have had at Yale. Very introspective class and if you care about migration this is wonderful to take. Plus I think this class will make you think about serious issues in a way that is provocative and needed for our time. Not superficial, not a class you are forced to participate in, a class you want to be in!
Yes! You read from many different voices to help you develop your own voice as a writer interested in diaspora and displacement

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: No other.
Zoom 2 hour seminar.
